official-title.#text:
Expressing the sense of the House of
		  Representatives that allocating the appropriate resources to wildland fire
		  management is needed to protect the environment, the economy, and the people of
		  the United States, and for other purposes.

committee-name.#tail:
, and in addition
			 to the Committee on

, for a period to be subsequently determined by the
			 Speaker, in each case for consideration of such provisions as fall within the
			 jurisdiction of the committee concerned

cosponsor.#tail:
) submitted the following
			 resolution; which was referred to the

text.#text: That it is the sense of the

a
			 healthy forest policy must include prescribed thinning;

the Government
			 should not continue to acquire more land when hundreds of millions of acres
			 already controlled by the Government are mismanaged; and

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
should proactively
			 manage Federal forest lands in a manner that—

text.#text: the

protects life and
			 property;

prevents
			 catastrophic wildfire;

promotes forest
			 and watershed health; and

creates jobs and
			 economic development in the forest products industry.

Whereas nearly 10 million acres of land burned in the
			 United States in 2012;

Whereas the acreage burned by wildfires has steadily
			 increased over the past decade;

Whereas the most destructive fire in the history of the
			 State of Colorado and the largest fire in the history of the State of New
			 Mexico destroyed hundreds of homes and hundreds of thousands of acres of
			 wildlife habitat in 2012;

Whereas Federal forest and land management officials
			 continue to request fewer funds to fight wildfires;

Whereas the Wildland Fire Hazardous Fuels Reduction
			 Account of the Forest Service was cut by $22 million from fiscal year 2011 to
			 fiscal year 2013 and the latest budget request asks for another $116 million
			 decrease;

Whereas senior Forest Service officials have described a
			 Federal land management system hamstrung by “analysis paralysis”;
Whereas the

Whereas the bark beetle epidemic has destroyed 40 million
			 acres of forest in North America; and

Whereas academic studies indicate that
			 bark-beetle-infected trees can still be salvaged for timber to be used in mills
			 and contribute to small businesses and local economies: Now, therefore, be
			 it

{http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/}title.#text: 113 HRES 279 IH: Expressing the sense of the House of Representatives that allocating the appropriate resources to wildland fire management is needed to protect the environment, the economy, and the people of the United States, and for other purposes.
